description: Fundamental historical concepts including major events, people, timelines, and civilizations
author: Bryan A. Spruk

entries.definition: Major early civilizations that shaped human development and culture
examples: Mesopotamia: 'Cradle of Civilization', invented writing
Egypt: Built pyramids as tombs for pharaohs
Greece: Birthplace of democracy and philosophy
Rome: Created extensive road networks and legal systems

entries.definition: Major global conflicts of the 20th century that reshaped the world
examples: WWI: First industrialized war, introduced tanks and chemical weapons
WWII: Deadliest conflict in history, led to nuclear age
Both wars involved most countries of the world

entries.definition: Period of rapid industrialization and technological advancement starting in Britain

value.location: Started in Britain, spread to Europe and North America

key_inventions.steam_engine: James Watt, powered factories and trains

social_impacts.urbanization: People moved from farms to cities
social_impacts.working_conditions: Long hours, child labor, dangerous factories

economic_impacts.mass_production: Goods became cheaper and more available

examples: Textile mills: Changed from hand production to machine production
Coal mining: Fueled steam engines and heated homes
Railroads: Revolutionized transportation and commerce

entries.definition: Struggle for racial equality and justice in the United States

key_figures.martin_luther_king_jr: Leader of nonviolent resistance, 'I Have a Dream' speech
key_figures.rosa_parks: Refused to give up bus seat, sparked Montgomery Bus Boycott
key_figures.malcolm_x: Advocated for Black nationalism and self-defense

legislation.civil_rights_act_1964: Outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin

examples: Sit-ins: Students sat at segregated lunch counters
Freedom Riders: Challenged segregation on buses
Bloody Sunday: Violent attack on marchers in Selma

entries.definition: Period of transformative change in scientific thought and methodology

key_figures.galileo: Telescope, experimental method, support for heliocentrism
key_figures.newton: Laws of motion and universal gravitation

key_developments.heliocentric_model: Sun at center of solar system
key_developments.experimental_method: Scientific method with observation and experimentation
key_developments.mathematical_modeling: Using mathematics to describe natural phenomena
key_developments.inductive_reasoning: Drawing general conclusions from specific observations

impacts.on_society: Challenged religious authority, promoted secular knowledge
impacts.on_education: Emphasis on empirical evidence and reason

examples: Copernicus: Published heliocentric theory in 1543
Galileo: Used telescope to observe moons of Jupiter
Newton: Published Principia Mathematica in 1687

entries.definition: Methods and principles for studying and interpreting historical events

value.secondary_sources: Interpretations and analyses of primary sources

historical_interpretation.context: Understanding events in their historical context
historical_interpretation.continuity_change: What stayed the same vs. what changed

chronological_frameworks.timelines: Visual representation of events over time

examples: Using diaries to understand daily life in the past
Cross-referencing multiple sources for accuracy
Analyzing political cartoons for social attitudes
Creating timelines to show cause-and-effect relationships
